text: Hey Barrett, please post your request so we could look what can be wrong
Hey Barret, it was happening the same to me i just changed “after” to 0 in my case, if it’s not sending an error, then is just something on the parameters

Hey everyone, i need to send some CRM info to my react-cms frontend (it’s connected to HubSpot) and i know i can’t do api calls from there, but my account doesn’t have serverless functions because it’s not enterprise level. Is there another option?
Big thaaanks :pray:

Hi <@U03C39A561X> I have the same issue and tried your syntax but I still have this error `Invalid input JSON on line 1, column 255: operator NOT_IN requires values`

here's my filter: `{ propertyName: 'hs_pipeline_stage', operator: 'NOT_IN', values: ["26409115", "26399331"] }`

Thanks for your help

It is frustrating that it got taken away, but what is most frustrating is that it is still listed in the documentation and one have to seek for a solution for hours to end up learning here that it is not available anymore... :angry:


<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/crm/search>
Please update the doc!

cc <@UD53A9UUR> I trust you can send the complain to the right team
That's just how the properties endpoint works

it does have the granular scope for it tho:
crm.objects.companies.read
and it specifically says or, not and
But you need a standard scope first...
You could also just use the schemas endpoint
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/crm/crm-custom-objects>
I like the schemas endpoints a lot more

Hey all, is there a way to track where a stray call to the API is coming from? We can see the endpoint but we cannot find where its originating from as all migration to the private apps is complete. Thanks!
Unless the call fails you really can't see the ip address of the call
At least I haven't found a way to do this
Not even through digging in the call object, I assume?
Thanks for the help, anyway! I guess its manual tracking now -.-
Yeah, hopefully soon we'll get an api for those logs

is it just me or are *SOME* (all? uncertain) of HubSpot’s API errors just impossible to parse? the JSON payload of what went wrong is stringified as part of the message. anyone have a fix?

```curl -X 'POST' '<https://api.hubapi.com/crm/v3/objects/deals>' \
-H "Accept: application/json, */*;q=0.8" \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer ..." \
--data-raw "{\"properties\":{\"email\":\"asd\"}}"
{"status":"error","message":"Property values were not valid: [{\"isValid\":false,\"message\":\"Property \\\"email\\\" does not exist\",\"error\":\"PROPERTY_DOESNT_EXIST\",\"name\":\"email\"}]","correlationId":"...","category":"VALIDATION_ERROR"}```
It appears that maybe you have stringified something wrong

my request is bad, I know that, but the thing is, the body response I get back from HubSpot is literally

```{"status":"error","message":"Property values were not valid: [{\"isValid\":false,\"message\":\"Property \\\"email\\\" does not exist\",\"error\":\"PROPERTY_DOESNT_EXIST\",\"name\":\"email\"}]","correlationId":"...","category":"VALIDATION_ERROR"}```
where the actual contents of the error are just a stringified json payload inside of the message
Yeah, it's because of the improper formatting of the body
Usually it comes in cleaner

<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/error-handling>

but the docs seem to indicate that the response body will have an errors property
improper formatting on HubSpot’s end, right?
No like you sent a badly formatted request and HubSpot is trying to send it back in a type safe way
but I didn’t, though. funny thing is, I generated this request through HubSpot’s Node client and just logged it out and converted it to curl
the same request on the docs
Yeah I agree it can definitely come in cleaner but underling thing is that HubSpot is just trying to send back the message in a type safe way
it can be type safe and still have the details not stringified in the message
sounds like I should reach out to HubSpot support?
Definitely that's always a good way to do things

<@U04DUMWKMGU> and <@U045GJFQQ20> thanks. I was not using UNIX in milliseconds for time values, which was causing the dates out of whack. Adding a few more zeros helped. FWIW, I was only able to find <https://legacydocs.HubSpot.com/docs/faq/how-should-timestamps-be-formatted-for-HubSpots-apis|this out through their legacy docs> and used <https://currentmillis.com/|this unix millisecond converter> to help troubleshoot.
I wasn't using milliseconds for my timestamp. I added 3 trailing zeros, or converted here and that helped: <https://currentmillis.com/>
Hi all, how can we insert data into foreign id column of hubDB table using HubDB API? I mean what's the structure of values object when we insert it via post http client.
